reviews.text: Lovely grounds, wonderful staff, beautiful beaches.. what more could you ask for?? We snooped around other resorts and we were so glad to have picked Hyatt. We were upgraded to a suite, and we had such beauitful ocean views with an acutal balcony. We were there to celebrate a big milestone, and I mentioned it to the staff in passing, and they suprised with chocolate cake and a bottle of red wine a little after we settlled in our suite. The grounds are beautiful, food is great (we ordered in a couple of times), Kadushi bar is too good (I could have lived off the pineapple, coconut smoothie) and of course, honorary mention of the talking parrots!! Too cute!!

Overall, its a bit pricy, but it was worth it for us as we were there for a special occassion, and hopefully, when we do go back, Hyatt would the resort of our choice!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Me and my husband just came back from a 4-night stay at the Hyatt Aruba. We had a wonderful time. The hotel is just beautiful. Nice landscaping, restaurants, and beach. It is also in a great location - across the street from many stores and restaurants. We were celebrating our anniversary and couldn't have picked a better place to stay. To help us remember our stay, the Hyatt added a few nice touches by surprising us with chocolates and a bottle of wine which was waiting for us in our room the first night. We were also offered a bottle of champagne to enjoy at one of their restaurants. We did have a very nice romantic dinner at Ruinas del Mar at the hotel. This was our best dinner while there. We also ate at Passions which was also nice, but we had higher expectations I think. Overall we had a great time and plan on staying at the Hyatt Aruba again.

The bed was very comfortable. The room was not huge but was big enough. The water at Palm Beach is beautiful. There are many tiki bars and other restaurants and shops within walking distance. There is really no reason to leave the area by car. We did go to the grocery store twice to buy beer which we took out to the beach, because the bar prices are pretty high. We also rented a car one day and drove to the other end of the island to Baby Beach. It really wasn't worth the expense and time because Baby Beach was hard to find and we didn't feel like hanging out there. It's a pretty beach but with no amenities. I guess we had been spoiled by the Hyatt.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2010, traveled with family
reviews.text: We selected this property based on TripAdvisor reviews as well as by taking a shot in the dark as we've never been to Aruba before and wanted to experience something unique for our honeymoon. We've stayed at all-inclusive resorts before in Mexico and Costa Rica, so this was our first "pay as you go" deal and we wanted nothing but the best to celebrate our honeymoon. I booked our package through AAVacations and had called the hotel to inform them to reserve the best available room and perhaps do something extra special for our honeymoon. Once we arrived to the property, it was all it was advertised - well maintained, luxurious, trendy open-air lobby, very clean, and yes we did expect kids and balconies with limited space. Admittedly, it was not a hotel for the money we spent as the rooms were not as roomy nor were there a walk out balcony where we can pull in a seat and smoke a cigar or have a drink while watching the sunset. Yet, we were very impressed with the cleanliness and daily/nightly turn-over service by the housekeeping staff. When we first arrived in our room, the ocean/island view was not what I expected so I asked management for an upgrade as it was "my honeymoon" and we didn't have a package or anything as I expected upon arrival, so they upgraded our room to a pool/ocean view two floors up and was a major IMPROVEMENT. The rooms, of course, was the same size but we couldn't complain with the upgraded view. The beach and outside restaurant locations across the street from the property was just perfect. We thought the Hyatt was probably the best hotel in Palm Beach, the hotel would have been the best of all Aruba, if the rooms were a bit roomier, had a complete walk out balcony, lower room and restaurant menu prices. Everything in Aruba is expensive (which is why we decided to splurge as it's our honeymoon - smile), so buy your stuff like water and beers from a mini mart (still expensive but half the price of hotel prices) and store them in a mini-fridge upon request and have your meals outside the property. Aruba food is quite the same across the board. We went to Charlie Tomato and Casa Tua for pizza. Went to Madame Jeanette's and Papimento for dinner - I'd go for Papimento purely for ambiance but beware of the mosquitoes there. We were attacked by them, folks did mention to bring bug spray even for the beach-side dinners. We had breakfast at Scala (nothing special), a NY-style bagel place which I thought was great, and DeliFrance - a breakfast haven but requires cab ride as it is close to downtown. We also wished that there were more papalyas on the beach, but surprisingly there were seats available throughout the day - mostly because July isn't a peak time there I guess. Had no problems grabbing pool seats. Wish the pools were a bit bigger though - be warned that there will be a bunch of kiddies if you're thinking of a romantic kid-free honeymoon, but didn't bother us that much since pretty much all of Aruba is kid-friendly. Hyatt was the luxury spot on the island, period. I may have heard somewhere that Riu might be more adults-oriented but we werent as impressed with the beach front area when we walked past the resort. The Marriott properties had even more kiddies and too crowded for our taste, so we concluded that the Hyatt was the best hotel in Palm Beach (I can't vouch for the other areas in Aruba as we are not as familiar with those sections). Although, we did take a snorkeling trip on the Black Pearl which we found really entertaining as we went on two stops and crew service was professional, clean, and impersonal. We also went on a Green Zebra 4x4 tomcar adventure - we enjoyed driving the tomcar, but found the snorkeling and cave stops a total bust. Don't get us wrong as the tomcar was a blast zooting around the national park, upclose look at the wind systems by the beach, a look at the natural bridge sibling, and a top-of-mountain look at all of Aruba and be able to catch a glimse of Venezuela which is only 20 miles away from the island. Really cool tour, but temper your expectations on some of the stops which I thought were unnecessary.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: In a word:"Gorgeous". The Hyatt Aruba is a magnificent property with beautiful gardens, winding paths, and easy access to pools and beach. With the embedded dining and bar areas, you need not leave the premises for all your basic daily needs, ie, sun and sea! BUT BE PREPARED.......Everything available on the hotel grounds (from basic coffee to fine wines and spirits, food, ancillaries, etc) is extremely expensive and overpriced: Banana in Starbucks: USD2. 1.5litre water: USD6.50. Hot dog in Palms Restaurant: USD11. Mixed salad on beach: USD15. The area around the hi-rise hotels is not much better. Expect to drop about USD50 for breakfast for two; about the same for lunch for two (with a soda or beer), and at least USD100 for dinner with a drink or beer. Since nothing but aloe and the land is indigenous to Aruba, everything is imported so the costs are high to begin with. Add this to the opulence of the hi-rise hotel area and you are going to spend bucks to eat. Sure you can do the burger king or pizza experience, but for how long? My suggestion: spring for the in-room fridge. If you dont have a car, have a taxi take you to the nearest super market and lay in a stock of breakfast and lunch stuff, and water / soda. You can then absorb dinner costs a bit easier.
reviews.title: Hyatt Aruba April 2013

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2013
reviews.text: Hyatt has every amenity you would want to have a great caribbean vacation. We took advantage of the spa as well which was outstanding! Cabs can take you anywhere for reasonable fare and to get to some places cabs are best, like to Madame Jeanette's which is somewhere outside the hotel district. Mights well be in another country....Let the cab do the work. If you want to stay local, you can walk out driveway and go left or right on the boulevard, with restaurants and shopping within an easy walk. Dinner reservations usually become a necessity if you want to eat say after 7pm.

A Rejuvenating Experience
reviews.text: My husband and I had a great vacation at the Hyatt Regency Aruba. We stayed five nights preceding Christmas.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2009, traveled solo
reviews.text: General Comments – The resort grounds are beautiful. As we awaited check-in on the Club Level, we received welcome cocktails. Our only complaint about the check-in process is several guests (including us) who reserved Club Level rooms were placed on other floors. However, Club Level access for cocktails and hor'dourves was still granted. Upper management was very accommodating when we expressed our concern. My husband and I usually prefer five-star properties such as Ritz Carltons and Four Seasons. However, this is our second stay at a Hyatt this year. Although the Hyatt Regency Aruba is a much different brand, the level of service we received from most of the staff was great. Admittedly, there were some sour apples in the bunch but we did not let them rain on our parade.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Room – Our room was meticulously cleaned. The pictures on the website accurately reflect the room, furniture, and décor. As others have mentioned, the balcony is basically non-existent. However, this was not a big deal for us. We simply opened the sliding door for a breeze or just stepped out for a few moments. As for the bathroom, we found the glass door and glass panel that separates the room really nice. In addition, we enjoyed the rain shower.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2009, traveled with family
reviews.text: Restaurants – The resort’s restaurants were pretty good. Café’ Jappengo, Ruinas del Mar, and the Palms were good. Café’ Piccolo was average. Meal expenses are comparable to Hyatt properties in the U.S. For instance, dinner for two (including two glasses of wine) was approximately $100. We paid nearly the same amount at a Hyatt in San Diego last spring. As others have mentioned, there are plenty of nearby restaurants.

reviews.text: My wife and I spent a week at the Hyatt Regency Aruba back in June. We don’t normally go to crowded vacation destinations, but we were combining a corporate trip and a mini vacation together. I’ll break down my summary of the Hyatt and Aruba into categories below.
reviews.title: Aruba-riba

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled with family
reviews.text: • Hyatt Regency Room – We stayed on the fourth floor, overlooking the swan pond, the Ruinas restaurant and a view of the beach area. The room was very well appointed with updated furniture. We had a king size bed which was very comfortable with lots of pillows. The AC worked very well. The room and bath area were very clean. The walk in shower with glass doors and 12” tiles had a wonderful ceiling mounted nozzle that felt more like a soothing rain than a shower. Our only complaint was that all the light fixtures had those stupid fluorescent, screw-in bulbs that give off little to no light. Ladies like a well lit bathroom. Balcony was small, but you don’t need to spend much time there with the beautiful beach just a few seconds away.
reviews.title: Consistently good!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: • Hyatt Regency Service – From our check-in to the check-out, everyone at the Hyatt was very friendly and helpful. Service with a smile makes all the difference. One fellow at the pool bar seemed a little overwhelmed, but he was mixing drinks for a lot of thirst pool goers. We did have one miscommunication with the papala rental, but the manager on duty straightened our reservation mix up out promptly.
reviews.title: Fun, sun and relaxing
Beautiful hotel and wonderful stay
reviews.text: • Hyatt Regency Food – We ate at the Palms for lunch on three different occasions. My fish tacos and chicken wraps were good, but bad luck plagued my wife. Her dish was brought out with a hair right on top, not once, but twice. Each time the staff promptly whisked the offending meal away and brought a freshly prepared one. They even treated us to a complementary beverage for our troubles. It happens I guess, but twice was strange. We ate breakfast at the Ruins where we had omelets to-order and large buffet of meat, fruits, cereals and yogurts. Nice, but around $50 for breakfast. We found the Salt-N-Pepper right across the street a delightful option for breakfast, serving great meals for about ½ the cost. A few more recommendations for food include the Driftwood located downtown (about $12 taxi from Hyatt) and Madame Janette (about $10 taxi from Hyatt). Both are great choices for seafood or steak.

The grounds are lush and tranquil and no hotel on the island has as many great restaurants and bars to choose from. The staff are always outstanding and actually seem to remember us from year to year.

reviews.text: Just returned from spending 5 nights at the Hyatt. It is a beautiful Hotel with friendly attentive staff. We were upgraded from a partial ocean view/island view to a partial ocean view/pool view. We were on a top floor and had a beautiful view of the ocean and the exquiste pool grounds. The room was an average size room but very clean and nice and we didn't find it to be "old", bathroom was just fine. You can get up early to reserve a hut, which we found were pretty much gone by 7:30 or if need be you can just go under the very large public hut right there on the beach. There was never a shortage of chairs at the beach.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2012
reviews.text: My boyfriend and I stayed at the Hyatt regency in Aruba for 8 days. The hotel had beautiful landscape and had iguanas crawling around the property. They also have parrots in cages and If your lucky u can see a couple of parrots kissing. But now comes what u really want to know. The rooms are nice and had an updated decore. The room had a balcony but not enough room to sit and enjoy the view but it has standing room only. The beach is beautiful and you can always sit under the large shade. We never had a problem finding room there. The swimming pool is small and filled with children and their toys. Just so u know anything u order in the hotel gets a 15% gratuity added even if the service is horrible. I say that because the service is horrible at the hotel bar, swim up bar and juice bar. For the money your are paying to stay here u figure they be a bit more happy and friendly towards the guest. We like the fact this hotel is centralized and in walking distance to all the great restaurants and shops. So don't worry u will have plenty of choices to dine at. Oh and almost forgot dnt miss happy hour at te beach bar just adjacent to the Hyatt for 2 drinks for only $8! Friendly service at that location.
reviews.title: Location, location, location!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Located right on the beach. Beautiful clear water, clean white sand surrounded by palm trees. Floats are provided by the hotel to use for 2 hours on the beach. One can relax and enjoy the cool island breeze without the usual bother of the locals. The only thing missing were hammocks. The restaurants are on the pricey side, breakfast buffet for two cost $50+, lunch was about the same. We had dinner off the property. Hibachi, Hooters, Smokey Joes, Senior Frogs and an Italian restaurant (don't recall the name) are nearby. Soenchi is close by if in need of authentic island cuisine. $10 per day for wifi or there's the option for a week. Overall, excellent stay and I'm ready for a revisit.

reviews.title: winter trip
reviews.text: We stayed at the Hyatt Regency Aruba during the week of January 5th, 2005. It is the best resort on the island. The grounds are beautiful and the rooms are comfortable and decorated nicely. The staff is friendly and helpful. We travel alot and understand that no vacation is perfect. Do not believe that it never rains in Aruba. It rained 5 of our 7 days. I only have two complaints. 1) Not very well-behaved young children roamed the property unsupervised. I observed one group catching lizards in the landscaping and pulling off their tails. 2) Reserving huts and chairs is a pain. I refused to get up at 6AM, so I got the leftovers. One day, I observed a hut left unoccupied for 3 hours. The hotel's written policy states that unoccupied huts would be reassigned after 2 hours. I asked for the hut. Because one chair under the hut had a towel on it , I was told that it couldn't be reassigned. No one ever returned to that hut that day. So, if you are an early riser, you can reserve a hut at the beach, chairs at the pool, and then spend the entire day shopping in town. What a system!

reviews.title: Average Honeymoon and Vacation
reviews.text: We spent a week at the Hyatt Regency from November 16-24, 2004. It was the second week of our honeymoon. The first week we spent in Mexico, Riviera Maya region at Secrets Capri. Go there if you want an amazing honeymoon and read my review.

reviews.title: Never Go
reviews.text: The weather was not great considering we choose Aruba for its "guaranteed" weather. It rained about 4 out of 7 days we were there. Not just 20 minute rain with sunshine but rain and then 3-4 hours of overcast and thick, thick clouds. We were told it had been like this for 3 weeks already as there was some front just sitting there not moving. Oh well not their fault.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2004
reviews.text: The hotel was average. The restaurants and food were excellent but the hallways were very tired looking and the carpet old and worn. It was definitely time for a face lift. We had prepaid for breakfast yet when we checked in they had no record of it and I had to show our itinerary from our travel agent. Our room was not ready and we were given 2 complimentary drink coupons and told to each lunch. That was ok. The food in all the restaurants was extremely expensive. $14.00 for a Cobb Salad and hamburger, etc. We went to the Wyndham hotel for a couples massage because it was $40 cheaper than our hotel.

Rain or shine, loved the Hyatt
reviews.text: We ate at various hotels and restaurants on the island which we enjoyed. The best Italian food was at Azzurro at the Playa del Linda Hotel next door to the Hyatt. Definitely go there and it was also the most reasonable about $60.00 for 2.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I stayed at the Hyatt the last week of January 2012. The grounds are beautiful. Our room was spacious and clean. I will say that the glass between the bathroom and the bed was troubling. If you get up in the middle night you end up lighting the whole room while someone else is trying to sleep. Just a little nit. We found the market to be helpful as it offered light breakfast and snack options. The Starbucks coffee was a nice touch. I really liked the location as you could walk to a number of restaurants and shops. The beach was spectacular. Based on the comments here, we did rent a palapa in advance which I found annoying to have to pay extra for but since it guaranteed us what we wanted so it was worth it the $35 a day. There was essentially no service on the beach. I did see a few waiters but they were hard to track down and not really seeking out people to serve. I did check out the gym one morning. It was fine for a holiday workout- several treadmills, a couple of ellipticals, some free weights and a universal machine. Check in was smooth, as was check out. The hotel staff was friendly and helpful, service was quick for the Caribbean and we enjoyed our stay very much. I am only rating it as average since nothing about it made it truly standout. I would have rated it as Good, if that had been an option.
reviews.title: Beautiful Hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2012

reviews.title: A little pricey, but worth it if you have the budget.
